body: Can this be merged?

Thanks for the review, Jesse & co. As correctly observed by Jan, the build fails due to cyclic references. I could probably fix them by moving some tests from `nbjunit` to `openide.util.lookup`, but then I got a better idea: let's fix two issues at once!

1. build should build code & tests
2. there should be `ant build` target in module projects

It is very unusual that the Ant harness module `build.xml` files don't have `build` target and one has to use `ant netbeans` instead. I can fix it as well as fix the build of tests:

1. let's add `<target name="build" depends="netbeans,test-build"/>` into `common.xml`
2. let's modify default targets of all modules in the `incubator-netbeans` repository to call `build`
2.a should there be any problem, people can change it back to `netbeans`
3. make sure build from the IDE calls `build` and not `netbeans`

This seems like more compatible and less drastic change which achieves the same thing: developers working on their own modules compile their code as well as tests.

I was silent for a while as I was unsure whether this proposal is good, but I still (even after two weeks) think it is... Shall I implement it?
Makes sense to me.
One note: it would be better to change the version in the binaries to 10. But I think we can do that on next update of the binaries.
I think you can proceed now, when beta of 9.0 is out and most of the licensing issues are resolved.

We sawn the leaf problem before. It has been solved in the `DialogDescriptor` by [isLeaf()](http://bits.netbeans.org/8.2/javadoc/org-openide-dialogs/org/openide/DialogDescriptor.html#isLeaf--) getter.

I don't understand why the current API isn't enough and there is a need for proposing `Leafable`.

What if someone had a `JDialog`, `JWindow`, or even a `JFrame` that would be difficult, impossible, undesirable, or a nightmare to convert to a `DialogDescriptor`? One such example is the "Popup" in `StatusLineComponent`. I am currently excluding `Window`s that are not a `Dialog` or a `Frame` since there might be many instances of those that we do not want to be a parent.

I am not UI/Swing expert - as such I can't guarantee using `DialogDisplayer` can solve all problems. Plus I tend to delay unnecessary API changes as much as possible. That is the reason I am asking for usage of existing APIs first - maybe, with a little fix, `DialogDisplayer.isLeaf` would be enough... 

This conservative approach has been like a double edged sword in the past, thus I am not sure the Apache NetBeans community wants to adopt it. If you get support from others, feel free to ignore my resistance.

Hooray, NetBeans harness now behaves almost like Maven! Btw.

>> We should just drop support for the Ant-based build harness IMO.
> Surely that would be a rather drastic 

Yes, the change of whole NetBeans build to use for example Maven would be so drastic that I hope nobody is willing to undertake it.

> PR itself sounds a good idea

Nobody, except Jesse. Rather don't tease him, as he is capable to do it. The only hope I have is that @jglick is busy with other tasks and will not find enough time either.

Why not changing the class name instead of adding a comment explaining why the name is no more relevant ?

Prefer using uppercase 'L' to denote long type (`0L` is more readable than `0l`)
Seems to be a problem in Travis.

> Why not changing the class name instead of adding a comment explaining why the name is no more relevant ?

Changing the name of this ant-task will lead to more changes in the build scripts itself. This pull-request just changes the source of the generated ID but not the "behavior" of the ant-task.
Looks good, thanks!
Please feel free to merge and also please mention on the dev@ mailing list that this is JDK 10 support in NetBeans.

@blackleg as noone seems to know what this test should test I suggest to remove it. We gain nothing by doing a fix that can't be verified. In other cases I voted to keep the test, as the test itself was fine, but only failed because files were not donated. In this case the test itself is the problem. Are you willing to do that?
@matthiasblaesing It seems right, I will update pull request to remove the test.

The Travis failure seems like a glitch in starting the job. I don't see a way to re-run that, so I'll close this PR and open a new one.

Please see:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-netbeans/pull/441
for approvals.

@jlahoda you can request travis-ci to restart a Job. In the travis status message click on "Show all checks", follow the "details" link and you will see the log of the failing test. Above the job log there is a summary about the job and that summary also contains a "Restart build" button.

You might need to create an account with travis-ci. I used that in the past with JNA (that has some flaky tests) and verified to info by checking PR #1005 which is failing right now. And I could restart that job.
Thanks for looking into this incident as I have temporary workaround because I am a NetBeans user.

@geertjanw thanks for looking into this - I assume the files were build from the sources contained in the `native` subdirectory of extbrowser? This currently breaks builds, because the Verification task fails:

```
/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-netbeans/nbbuild/build.xml:1532: Failed VerifyLibsAndLicenses test(s):
Some license files have incorrect headers
extbrowser/external/extbrowser-dlls.zip does not appear to include a version number
extbrowser/external/extbrowser-dlls.zip is not associated with any license file
```

I suggest to rename the zip to something like `extbrowser-dlls-<year><month><day>.zip` to satisfy the "requires version" requirement. For the "license file requirement" a file `extbrowser-dlls-<year><month><day>-license.txt` is required. Assuming the files were build from the CDDL sources, `lib.profiler/external/profiler-external-binaries-8.2-license.txt` can be used as a template.

I think the question also is whether a ZIP file containing the two DLLs is the right approach. Maybe the two DLLs need to be listed separately in the binaries-list, i.e., they'd then be downloaded as DLLs and automatically put in the right place since they'd be in the 'external' folder. That could be better than downloading a ZIP file which will then somehow need to be unzipped?

1 Are there any other .Kind for which control comes here?

2 Why startsWith check? Can we check for equals here.

3 If we are using any constant strings, we should add a line comment //NOI18N to skip flagging by nls audit tool.
Not really sure what license to use, so followed @matthiasblaesing suggestion above.
A question at this point that remains is whether 18.03.15 (i.e., today's date) makes sense as a version number.

Added rtaneja1 review comment as:
1 Are there any other .Kind for which control comes here?
--> Remove the kind check
2 Why startsWith check? Can we check for equals here.
--> Can't use code.equals("var "), because code has full statement as String.
3 If we are using any constant strings, we should add a line comment //NOI18N to skip flagging by nls audit tool.
--> Implemented
I haven't checked, but VariableTree.type's position may be -1 in this case. In that case check also in syntax with multiple declarators like `int a,b;`

Hi, the date should be fine but see what the previous versions
reported.  I think the files should be listed in
the binary-list.  How are other similar dll being handled?


from NB 8.2 reports:
org.netbeans.modules.extbrowser                    1.53.1
          Enabled

from NB 8.0.2 reports:
org.netbeans.modules.extbrowser                    1.48.1
   Enabled

Maybe this release if not the date, use 1.54.1, the date is easier to
remember and document.

My vote is for the date because I have not background on the original
versioning.

Regards,

Efrem McCrimon (efremmc2)

I'd rather not merge API changes until the second donation is complete, as many users download and use plugins from previous NetBeans versions. I'm not sure what the impact could be on those old plugins. I think it would be good evaluating this impact.
Native libs are handled in this way generally, i.e., theyre made available and registered in a ZIP file, then unzipped and put in the right place during the build.
The tests seem to be passing, I assume. +1 then.

I believe the requested tests are more important. I haven't had time to turn the presented examples from this thread into tests (or more importantly learn how to turn them in to appropriate NetBeans tests).

I am still somewhat resistant to adding an option. In the current proposed patch the effect is for the source reformatter to **not**  insert extra braces that the user did not enter when performing reformatting, ie. the reformatter makes fewer changes to user code. If the user did include braces then they are preserved.

If user enables the existing remove braces option then reformatting will remove the "extra" braces around some try/synchronized statements, however since it also removes them from conditionals with single statement bodies it is probably not a widely used option and those who use it must really hate braces.

+1, but please squash the commits into one. We don't need to go back and forth four times to change three lines of code!

PS: Unless the history of changes is somewhat important, of course...

+1, although longer term if we have more of these UI's, might be good to look at generating some of this from the look and feel info?

Incidentally, there is a squash and merge action for PR's in the GitHub UI.
Any objections against merging this? (We need to work on getting this into the binary .exe/.dll though.)
One question: there's a hint to convert an implicit lambda to explicit lambda; that still works, right? Besides this, I don't see a reason why not merge this.
OK lets merge.
Makes sense to me.

I checked the hint Jan mentioned and it indeed still works. Merging this.
Overall, updating this dependency seems finicky. I would suggest we just repackage jgit ourselves.

Hi,

Sorry for delay. Some initial comments:
-please note that every occurrence of @Hint means a separate "hint" and a separate entry in Tools/Options/Editor/Hints. I think there should only be a single @Hint for this (on the class), which means a single hint/single configuration entry, and then there can be any number of @Trigger methods inside the class that will all work for that single hint. Some conversion may be seen undesirable (worsening readability), so it might be desirable to allow disabling the conversion in some contexts, although I am not sure offhand for which it should be. Defining simple boolean options should be simple, see @BooleanOption, e.g. in: java.hints/src/org/netbeans/modules/java/hints/perf/SizeEqualsZero.java
-please note that @Hint has minSourceVersion that can be used to specify minimal -source version for the hint. But even if that didn't work in a particular case, there is CompilationInfo.getSourceVersion(), which should be used instead of SourceLevelQuery in hints.
-category = "suggestions" -> category = "rules15" (the category name is confusing, but it is not easy to change; this will be under "JDK Migration Support")
-I wonder if the hint shouldn't have simply @TriggerTreeKind(VARIABLE) or @TriggerPattern("$mods$ $type $var =new $init;") and then internally trying to figure out if the variable can be var or not. (Also please note there will soon be an API method to check if a variable is "var" or not that the hint will be able to use.)
Looks good and works for me.

As far as I can say this is exactly the change that @geertjanw [requested on the mailing list](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/incubator-netbeans-dev/201803.mbox/%3CCACkjAxQqM0FvXTPevpUf6yU7_LDB9ePxLB2jwW%2BCr1fx2hW06g%40mail.gmail.com%3E).

Any objections against merging this?

Thanks.
Specification version changed, apichanges.xml should mention the public API change.
I think 'Java GUI Application' is maybe a bit misleading/too general, shouldn't it be "DukeScript Application" or "HTML/Java API Application"?
Discussed with Jan Lahoda, myself, Vikas -- we're OK with this and merging.

Thanks for the review, @geertjanw! I agree the classification of the wizard as **GUI** is general. But it is not incorrect. Quite opposite. Dmitry [pointed out when trying to use the wizard](http://mail-archives.apache.org/mod_mbox/incubator-netbeans-dev/201803.mbox/%3CCAM6-voFo4bvdWp_7gmV6PMEECXbT5FwXksMd9mjSTmuafTWjSQ%40mail.gmail.com%3E) that a proper name for the wizard is needed:

> Select: File -> New Project -> JavaFX -> Java HTML5 Application (again,
> only because I knew from this thread where to click)
> Read description: "Generates a WebView based DukeScript application".
>
> DukeScript? WebView based?... huh...

Based on his feedback I'd like to avoid mentioning **DukeScript** or **WebView** or **HTML** in the wizard name or its description. It is too confusing. Either people don't know what the term means, or they start to think about *servlets*, *JSPs*, etc. None of that is what they get. They will really get **GUI**.
Maybe 'Java HTML GUI Application' then? To me and probably many having used NetBeans ever, GUI signifies Java Swing.
OK, I think.

I like Geertjans suggestion - it is simple and transports the necessary info. 

If you want a simple self-contained application without external dependencies there is currently Swing as the build-in GUI. HTML GUIs that are created here are different beast and the user should be able to see that.
Agree with Matthias on Geertjan's wording.  Can I clarify what happens when a user doesn't have JavaFX?  Is the project _and the wizard_ still usable?
I agree. The change looks safe. Merging.

Thank you for your review & question, Jan, and thank you, Matthias, for
following up.  I am sorry for not responding earlier; I have been traveling
without my computer.
